protocol_name: Fabrication and Deployment of the In Situ Chemotaxis Assay (ISCA)
protocol_name_html: Fabrication and Deployment of the In Situ Chemotaxis Assay (ISCA)
description: Here we outline the process of fabricating and deploying the In Situ Chemotaxis Assay (ISCA) and its deployment enclosure.
before_start:
In the supplementary information of the paper describing the ISCA (http://go.nature.com/2wxGhzg) you can find the .stl file necessary for 3D printing the device mould. You can 3D print the mould yourself, but we recommend hiring a service to carry out the print for you. The surface finish of the mould is very important (it should be as smooth as possible), as that determines how well the ISCA structure bonds to the glass substrate, which in turn ensures there’s no cross-contamination between wells. For that reason, we recommend using the same type of printer (Objet30 3D printer, Stratasys) and polymer (VeroGrey) as described in the paper.

 

Before using new ISCA moulds, it is recommended to soak them in deionized water for at least 24hrs to remove any readily soluble contaminants, and then incubate at 40°C overnight to ensure that they are completely dry before first use.
warning:
• When using a plasma wand, it is a good idea to do so in a well-ventilated area.
  • Acrylic solvents are both flammable and toxic. Handle them with care in a well-ventilated area.
  • Always cut away from yourself.
protocol_affiliation: Massachusetts Institute of Technology,University of Technology Sydney
status_info: The current protocol in use by our groups.

components.data: Assembling the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Cast 26g of 1:10 (curing agent:base) polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS aka. Sylgard 184) onto the 3D printed moulds.  Here, it is of critical importance that the PDMS is degassed under vacuum and that there are no bubbles left within the mould.

 

We use a process similar to that described here in order to reduce the degassing time: (http://blogs.rsc.org/chipsandtips/2013/10/02/periodic-degassing-of-pdms-to-create-a-perfect-bubble-free-sample/).
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Cast 26g of 1:10 (curing agent:base) polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS aka. Sylgard 184) onto the 3D printed moulds.  Here, it is of critical importance that the PDMS is degassed under vacuum and that there are no bubbles left within the mould.

 

We use a process similar to that described here in order to reduce the degassing time: (http://blogs.rsc.org/chipsandtips/2013/10/02/periodic-degassing-of-pdms-to-create-a-perfect-bubble-free-sample/).

components.data: Assembling the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data: Cure the PDMS overnight at 40 °C. The deflection point of the polymer used for 3D printing (VeroGrey) is 48 °C, so it is best not to approach that value or you may deform your moulds. It is really important here that the moulds are cured on a level surface to reduce variability between wells. Generally having no more than 6 moulds curing at a time is preferable, unless you have a large and level area for curing.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Cure the PDMS overnight at 40 °C. The deflection point of the polymer used for 3D printing (VeroGrey) is 48 °C, so it is best not to approach that value or you may deform your moulds. It is really important here that the moulds are cured on a level surface to reduce variability between wells. Generally having no more than 6 moulds curing at a time is preferable, unless you have a large and level area for curing.

components.data: Assembling the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Cut along the edges of the mould using a scalpel (be gentle and try to cut as close as possible to the edge). Please note: do not attempt to cut the PDMS very close to the wells or you will compromise the surface finish of the mould, which will result in improper bonding when the mould is reused. Very gently peel the PDMS layer out of the mould, making sure not to tear the edges.

 

 

Figure 1. Cut carefully around the cured PDMS layer, near the edge of the mould.

 

 

Figure 2. Use the scalpel to carefully peel the edges of the PDMS layer away from the mould.

 

 

Figure 3. Carefully continue to peel the PDMS layer out of the mould until it completely detaches.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Cut along the edges of the mould using a scalpel (be gentle and try to cut as close as possible to the edge). Please note: do not attempt to cut the PDMS very close to the wells or you will compromise the surface finish of the mould, which will result in improper bonding when the mould is reused. Very gently peel the PDMS layer out of the mould, making sure not to tear the edges.

 

 

Figure 1. Cut carefully around the cured PDMS layer, near the edge of the mould.

 

 

Figure 2. Use the scalpel to carefully peel the edges of the PDMS layer away from the mould.

 

 

Figure 3. Carefully continue to peel the PDMS layer out of the mould until it completely detaches.

components.data: Assembling the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Trim the edges of the PDMS slab with a scalpel (approximately 1 cm on each side) to remove the uneven portions at the edge of the PDMS slab.

 

 

 

Figure 4. Trim away the rough edges using a scalpel. The surface that will be bonded should face up during this process to reduce accumulation of debris, which impacts bonding.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Trim the edges of the PDMS slab with a scalpel (approximately 1 cm on each side) to remove the uneven portions at the edge of the PDMS slab.

 

 

 

Figure 4. Trim away the rough edges using a scalpel. The surface that will be bonded should face up during this process to reduce accumulation of debris, which impacts bonding.

source_data.body: It should go without saying -- always cut away from yourself. In this step take care.

components.data: Assembling the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Clean the ISCA ports with an 18G syringe needle. This is a critical step and making sure all the ports are not obstructed has a strong effect on observed variability.

We typically sharpen the edges of the needles down to the correct port diameter. Alternatively, a biopsy punch of the appropriate diameter (0.8 mm) can be used.

 

 

Figure 5. Remove obstructions from the ports using a biopsy punch or syringe tip.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Clean the ISCA ports with an 18G syringe needle. This is a critical step and making sure all the ports are not obstructed has a strong effect on observed variability.

We typically sharpen the edges of the needles down to the correct port diameter. Alternatively, a biopsy punch of the appropriate diameter (0.8 mm) can be used.

 

 

Figure 5. Remove obstructions from the ports using a biopsy punch or syringe tip.

components.data: Assembling the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data: Clean the PDMS slab using scotch tape. This removes dust and debris from the surface.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Clean the PDMS slab using scotch tape. This removes dust and debris from the surface.

components.data: Assembling the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data: UV-sterilise the PDMS slab for 30 minutes together with a clean glass slide (use 80% Ethanol, followed by a ddH2O rinse).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: UV-sterilise the PDMS slab for 30 minutes together with a clean glass slide (use 80% Ethanol, followed by a ddH2O rinse).

components.data: Assembling the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data: Plasma-bond the PDMS slab to a glass slide. You can either use a plasma wand or plasma oven for this step. We prefer a plasma oven, as it ensures uniform formation of covalent bonds when the device is assembled.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Plasma-bond the PDMS slab to a glass slide. You can either use a plasma wand or plasma oven for this step. We prefer a plasma oven, as it ensures uniform formation of covalent bonds when the device is assembled.

components.data: Assembling the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data: Place the devices (glass down) on a hotplate at 80 °C for ~30 minutes after plasma bonding in order to accelerate the formation of covalent bonds.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the devices (glass down) on a hotplate at 80 °C for ~30 minutes after plasma bonding in order to accelerate the formation of covalent bonds.

components.data: Assembling the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data: Cover the top of the PDMS slab with clean scotch tape. This keeps the top surface clean and prevents dust and debris from entering the ports while the device is stored.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Cover the top of the PDMS slab with clean scotch tape. This keeps the top surface clean and prevents dust and debris from entering the ports while the device is stored.

components.data: Before heading to the field, it is important to build the flow-damping enclosure. In the supplementary information of the paper we provide the .ai file, which can be used to laser-cut the pieces needed to build the enclosure. Again this can be done in house, but you can also outsource this step to a design company.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Before heading to the field, it is important to build the flow-damping enclosure. In the supplementary information of the paper we provide the .ai file, which can be used to laser-cut the pieces needed to build the enclosure. Again this can be done in house, but you can also outsource this step to a design company.

components.data: Assembling the Flow-Damping Enclosure
components.name: Section

components.data: Assembling the Flow-Damping Enclosure
components.name: Section

components.data: Once you have the acrylic pieces we generally fasten them together using Weld-On 3 and let the assembly cure overnight. The pieces are designed to fit together in a puzzle-like fashion. A drawing of the assembled enclosure is provided in the supplementary material of the paper.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once you have the acrylic pieces we generally fasten them together using Weld-On 3 and let the assembly cure overnight. The pieces are designed to fit together in a puzzle-like fashion. A drawing of the assembled enclosure is provided in the supplementary material of the paper.

components.data: Assembling the Flow-Damping Enclosure
components.name: Section

components.data: Once the bonds have hardened, it’s again a good idea to soak the enclosures in deionized water for 24 hrs - prior to use.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once the bonds have hardened, it’s again a good idea to soak the enclosures in deionized water for 24 hrs - prior to use.

components.data: Preparing Chemoattractants and Controls
components.name: Section

components.data: Collect water from the field site in a 50 mL Falcon tube. (Immediately prior to experiments)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Collect water from the field site in a 50 mL Falcon tube. (Immediately prior to experiments)

components.data: Preparing Chemoattractants and Controls
components.name: Section

components.data: First filter gently (without applying excessive pressure) through a 0.2 μm Sterivex filter.  Use 10 mL sterile syringes for filtration (smaller syringes apply too much pressure and compromise the filtration process).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: First filter gently (without applying excessive pressure) through a 0.2 μm Sterivex filter.  Use 10 mL sterile syringes for filtration (smaller syringes apply too much pressure and compromise the filtration process).

components.data: Preparing Chemoattractants and Controls
components.name: Section

components.data:
Filter through 0.2 μm Millex FG filter.

 

 

Figure 6. Filter seawater from the site carefully into a Falcon tube.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Filter through 0.2 μm Millex FG filter.

 

 

Figure 6. Filter seawater from the site carefully into a Falcon tube.

components.data: Preparing Chemoattractants and Controls
components.name: Section

components.data: Finally, filter through a 0.02 μm Whatman filter. It is quite difficult to get water through this last filter, so we recommend carefully assessing the amount of water needed for your experiment before starting the last filtration step. This process, when done properly, ensures complete removal of bacterial cells from seawater and provides a safe medium to resuspend your chemoattractants (it also has the same salinity/density and nutrient content as the bulk seawater surrounding the ISCA, providing an ideal negative control for the assay).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Finally, filter through a 0.02 μm Whatman filter. It is quite difficult to get water through this last filter, so we recommend carefully assessing the amount of water needed for your experiment before starting the last filtration step. This process, when done properly, ensures complete removal of bacterial cells from seawater and provides a safe medium to resuspend your chemoattractants (it also has the same salinity/density and nutrient content as the bulk seawater surrounding the ISCA, providing an ideal negative control for the assay).

components.data: Preparing Chemoattractants and Controls
components.name: Section

components.data: Use this water to dilute chemoattractants to the desired final concentration and collect what remains as negative controls (for both flow cytometry and sequencing). Generally, we run dilution series experiments with each chemoattractant to determine the optima before a field campaign.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Use this water to dilute chemoattractants to the desired final concentration and collect what remains as negative controls (for both flow cytometry and sequencing). Generally, we run dilution series experiments with each chemoattractant to determine the optima before a field campaign.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Fill the wells of the device using a 27G syringe needle and a 1 mL sterile syringe, with the port facing up. This allows fluid to enter the well, while air vents through the port. Fill the well slowly to ensure an even fill, up to the point where a small droplet comes out of the port on the top surface of the device. This is really important as it ensures there is no air bubble trapped within the port, which will prevent the diffusion of the chemicals out of the device and therefore the recruitment of bacteria in the wells.

 

 

Figure 7. Fill the wells carefully with solutions. Here, angling the device ensures air vents from the port.

 

 

Figure 8. It is very important to leave a droplet above the port when filling. This prevents air bubbles from getting trapped in the port.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Fill the wells of the device using a 27G syringe needle and a 1 mL sterile syringe, with the port facing up. This allows fluid to enter the well, while air vents through the port. Fill the well slowly to ensure an even fill, up to the point where a small droplet comes out of the port on the top surface of the device. This is really important as it ensures there is no air bubble trapped within the port, which will prevent the diffusion of the chemicals out of the device and therefore the recruitment of bacteria in the wells.

 

 

Figure 7. Fill the wells carefully with solutions. Here, angling the device ensures air vents from the port.

 

 

Figure 8. It is very important to leave a droplet above the port when filling. This prevents air bubbles from getting trapped in the port.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Once all the wells are filled (remember to use a different syringe and tip for each solute), place the device into the flow-damping enclosure. The device can be fixed in place using double-sided scotch tape.

 

 

Figure 9. The ISCA taped in place within the flow-damping enclosure.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Once all the wells are filled (remember to use a different syringe and tip for each solute), place the device into the flow-damping enclosure. The device can be fixed in place using double-sided scotch tape.

 

 

Figure 9. The ISCA taped in place within the flow-damping enclosure.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Tape all the seams and holes (except the bottom hole) of the enclosure with scotch tape.

 

 

 

Figure 10. Seal the flow-damping enclosure with scotch tape. Place the vertical strip after securing the top and bottom halves together. This allows slow release of water after deployment.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Tape all the seams and holes (except the bottom hole) of the enclosure with scotch tape.

 

 

 

Figure 10. Seal the flow-damping enclosure with scotch tape. Place the vertical strip after securing the top and bottom halves together. This allows slow release of water after deployment.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Fix the enclosure onto a stable deployment arm. We use modified wood clamps that can be attached to a solid structure (e.g. wharf, ladder, pillar) and have a small platform for the enclosure (see picture).

 

 

Figure 11. The flow-damping enclosure fixed to the deployment arm. We use bungy cords to fix the enclosure to a modified clamp.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Fix the enclosure onto a stable deployment arm. We use modified wood clamps that can be attached to a solid structure (e.g. wharf, ladder, pillar) and have a small platform for the enclosure (see picture).

 

 

Figure 11. The flow-damping enclosure fixed to the deployment arm. We use bungy cords to fix the enclosure to a modified clamp.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Place the box in the water and let the enclosure fill slowly (the slower the better), until all air has escaped from the enclosure. It is important to vent any air bubbles in the enclosure, as their presence will increase the fluid flow inside the enclosure and could negatively impact the outcome of the experiment.

 

 

Figure 12. Lowering the enclosure into the sea. In this step try to minimize movement of the enclosure during filling.

 

 

Figure 13. The enclosure should fill slowly while submerged.

 

 

Figure 14. It is very important no bubbles remain within the enclosure. To accomplish this, angle the enclosure so that the air vent (top right of box; shown here) is the highest point.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Place the box in the water and let the enclosure fill slowly (the slower the better), until all air has escaped from the enclosure. It is important to vent any air bubbles in the enclosure, as their presence will increase the fluid flow inside the enclosure and could negatively impact the outcome of the experiment.

 

 

Figure 12. Lowering the enclosure into the sea. In this step try to minimize movement of the enclosure during filling.

 

 

Figure 13. The enclosure should fill slowly while submerged.

 

 

Figure 14. It is very important no bubbles remain within the enclosure. To accomplish this, angle the enclosure so that the air vent (top right of box; shown here) is the highest point.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Once the enclosure is full, plug the bottom hole using a 20 μL pipette tip that has been modified to act as a seal (see picture).

 

 

Figure 15. Modified pipette tip used to plug enclosure inlet.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Once the enclosure is full, plug the bottom hole using a 20 μL pipette tip that has been modified to act as a seal (see picture).

 

 

Figure 15. Modified pipette tip used to plug enclosure inlet.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Wait. In warm waters we deploy each ISCA for 1 hr.

 

 

 

Figure 16. Fix the deployment arm and wait for the duration of the experiment.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Wait. In warm waters we deploy each ISCA for 1 hr.

 

 

 

Figure 16. Fix the deployment arm and wait for the duration of the experiment.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data: Pull the enclosure out of the water and set it on as level of a surface as possible.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Pull the enclosure out of the water and set it on as level of a surface as possible.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data:
Progressively unseal (from top-to-bottom) each drain hole. This slowly drains water from the enclosure, (the slower the better). It should take approximately 5 minutes to drain the contents of the box.

 

 

Figure 17. Begin unsealing the drain holes along the side of the enclosure. Carry out this step one hole at a time, allowing the water level to fall to the height of the hole that is uncovered.

 

 

Figure 18. Continue slowly until the enclosure is empty.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Progressively unseal (from top-to-bottom) each drain hole. This slowly drains water from the enclosure, (the slower the better). It should take approximately 5 minutes to drain the contents of the box.

 

 

Figure 17. Begin unsealing the drain holes along the side of the enclosure. Carry out this step one hole at a time, allowing the water level to fall to the height of the hole that is uncovered.

 

 

Figure 18. Continue slowly until the enclosure is empty.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data: Remove the ISCA from the drained enclosure and place it on clean Kimwipes to soak excess water from the glass slide. Using a pipette, remove all remaining water droplets from the ISCA top surface, ensuring it is as dry as possible.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove the ISCA from the drained enclosure and place it on clean Kimwipes to soak excess water from the glass slide. Using a pipette, remove all remaining water droplets from the ISCA top surface, ensuring it is as dry as possible.

components.data: Deploying the ISCA
components.name: Section

components.data: Change your gloves and draw well contents slowly with a 1 mL sterile syringe and 27G syringe needle, with the port facing down. Pool the technical replicates (typically 5 ISCA wells/one row) to ensure you get enough material for DNA extraction and cell counts. Out of this pooled volume, 80 μL is typically fixed in glutaraldehyde (2% final concentration) and the remaining volume is flash frozen for subsequent DNA extraction.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Change your gloves and draw well contents slowly with a 1 mL sterile syringe and 27G syringe needle, with the port facing down. Pool the technical replicates (typically 5 ISCA wells/one row) to ensure you get enough material for DNA extraction and cell counts. Out of this pooled volume, 80 μL is typically fixed in glutaraldehyde (2% final concentration) and the remaining volume is flash frozen for subsequent DNA extraction.
